name: Confederation of Sahel States
ariaLabel: Flags of Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger
currentCrisisSummary:
The Central Sahel (Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger) suffers a severe crisis born from converging **structural violence**: weak governance inherited from **colonialism** and gutted by **neoliberalism**, jihadist insurgencies fuelled by **state collapse** and **foreign interventions**, recurrent **coups** reflecting popular rejection of **neo-colonial** security models, and accelerating **climate shocks**.

Recent military takeovers signal a shift, creating a new **geopolitical** frontline. Violence, driven by armed groups and **predatory control of resources**, inflicts mass displacement and starvation. The human cost is amplified by long-term **extractive relations** and **external interference**. Ending the suffering requires Sahelian-led political solutions and dismantling **extractive** and **militarised responses** imposed from outside.

colonialRoot.legacy:
**French colonial rule** reorganised borders and economies favouring **extraction**. At independence, formal sovereignty didn't erase these structures: monetary arrangements (**CFA franc**), security pacts, and '**FranÃ§afrique**' networks allowed continued French influence.

These arrangements left fragile states, **export-oriented economies**, and weak governance, conditions contributing to later instability.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberalism and the Hollowed-Out State
historicalContext.description: During debt crises (1980s-90s), Sahelian states adopted **IMF/World Bank-led Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs)**. These **neoliberal policies** mandated severe **austerity**, dismantling public services. This '**hollowing out**' of the state created a governance vacuum, destroyed livelihoods, and eroded trust, a root cause of current insurgencies.

historicalContext.title: The War on Terror and Failed Interventions
historicalContext.description: Post-2001, the Sahel became a frontier in the global '**War on Terror**', prioritising militarised responses. The 2011 **NATO-led intervention in Libya** dismantled a state, creating a **power vacuum** fuelling the 2012 Mali insurgency. Subsequent **French interventions** (Operation Barkhane) continued this security-first approach, creating **dependency** and backlash leading to **anti-French coups**.

historicalContext.title: Resource Extraction and Neo-Colonialism
historicalContext.description: Poverty contrasts with mineral wealth coveted by **foreign powers**. Niger's strategic **uranium** supply for France exemplifies **neo-colonial** relations: French state corporations extract profits while Niger remains impoverished. This **resource plunder** drives **anti-French sentiment**.

historicalContext.title: Climate Change and Regional Instability
historicalContext.description: The Sahel is on the frontline of the **climate emergency** despite minimal emissions. Desertification undermines livelihoods, worsening resource competition. This is **climatic injustice** or '**climate colonialism**', where costs of Northern industrialisation are borne by Sahelian communities.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Calls grow for **accountability** around military support, arms trafficking, and **resource exploitation** sustaining armed groups. UN panels document **illicit resource flows** and external support; addressing these is essential for peace and **reparative justice**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands killed by violence from insurgencies, **state repression**, and conflict exacerbated by **external interference**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Est. 18 million require aid due to breakdown caused by **conflict**, **neoliberal policies**, and **climate shocks**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions face acute hunger, driven by **conflict**, **climate change**, and failed development models.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 3.3 million internally displaced by **jihadist attacks**, military operations, and resource conflicts linked to **climate change**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Nearly 1 million forced abroad by violence and **state collapse**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of health centres closed due to attacks, insecurity, and underfunding rooted in **austerity**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Large populations lack safe water due to conflict and state incapacity from **neoliberal hollowing-out**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Denied
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions of children denied education as schools closed by insecurity from armed groups and **failed state responses**.

timeline.event: **French Conquest**: France consolidates control across West Africa, imposing borders and administrative systems that reconfigured local polities.
**Nominal Independence**: Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger gain independence but remain embedded in post-colonial monetary and security arrangements linked to France.
**NATO Intervention in Libya**: The collapse of Libya's state after 2011 disperses weapons and fighters across the Sahel, amplifying regional insecurity.
**Northern Mali Insurgency**: A Tuareg rebellion in northern Mali is overtaken by jihadist groups, triggering a major regional crisis.

**Operation Barkhane & French Engagement**: France deploys Operation Barkhane and other counter-insurgency efforts across the Sahel; despite sustained military effort, jihadist violence spreads and French strategy becomes a focal point for criticism.
**Wave of Coups**: Military juntas seize power in Mali, Burkina Faso and Niger (among others), expel French forces in many cases and contest existing regional security structures.

**Confederation of Sahel States**: Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso form a confederation that signals a break with ECOWAS and existing Francophone security arrangements, shifting the region's geopolitical alignments.
**Deepening Crisis**: Violence intensifies in many areas as jihadist groups and intercommunal conflict spread, producing rising displacement, protection crises and severe humanitarian need.

advocacy: Push for a shift away from militarised counter-terrorism strategies towards Sahelian-led political, social and development solutions that address root causes.
Demand transparency and enforceable corporate due diligence on mineral and agricultural supply chains that link Northern consumption to local dispossession.
Advocate for climate reparations and increased, flexible climate finance for locally led adaptation and resilience-building projects.
Call for targeted measures to cut illicit arms flows and for international mechanisms to investigate and sanction external actors found to be materially supporting armed groups.
